entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud app get selection row
entry.content:
Hello @JamesG 

Thank you for reaching out to the SAP Community and your questions

Here are the two clean patterns for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition (Fiori elements, OData V4):

List Report (table selection)

onCustomAction: function () {

  const extApi = this.base.getExtensionAPI();

  const ctxs = extApi.getSelectedContexts();           // v4 Context[]

  if (!ctxs.length) { sap.m.MessageBox.warning("Select a row first."); return; }

  const rowData = ctxs[0].getObject();                 // plain JS object

  // ...use rowData (or ctxs.map(c => c.getObject()) for multi-select)

}

Object Page

onCustomOPAction: function () {

  const ctx = this.base.getExtensionAPI().getBindingContext();

  if (!ctx) { return; }

  const obj = ctx.getObject();                         // header data

}

 

If you require rows from a specific sub-table on the Object Page:

const selected = this.base.getExtensionAPI().getSelectedContexts("MyStableTableID");

const firstRow = selected[0]?.getObject();

Check below SAP references

SAPUI5 Demo Kit  sap.fe.core.ExtensionAPI (OData V4): API offering getSelectedContexts() and getBindingContext() methods for List Report and Object Page controllers’ extensions. SAPUI5 SDK-Discover New Enterprise Grade Horizons

SAP Help Portal Using the extension API (Fiori elements V4): When and where to utilise the Extension API in controller extensions. SAP Help Portal-Using the extension API

Let me know if you need further information

Best regards,
Chuma

entry.title: Re: Distribution Channel set-up cause issue in DRF Replic...
entry.content:
Hi,

It seems that there's a concept supported by the SAP standard called a cross-functional distribution channel. By using it, you can save database space by assigning your customers and products to this cross-functional DC, which can then be used across all specific distribution channels.

So far, so good. However, if your customizing does not also enable the Sales View for this cross-functional DC (and in our case, we do not want to create Sales Orders using the cross-functional DC), then the Sales Arrangement data (i.e., Sales View-specific data) of your Business Partner (BuPa) will not be replicated via DRF to the S/4 clients.

So far, I haven't found any BAdI that would allow us to include our cross-functional DC as a valid combination. However, if you activate it in customizing, the replication of Sales Arrangement data works. Of course, this solution comes with some issues, and I would definitely prefer to solve this via a BAdI — so let's see.

Best regards,
Milan

entry.title: SAP Green Token for EUDR: Simplifying Compliance at Scale
entry.content:
The EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) is reshaping how companies source and trade key commodities in the EU. From December 2025, large companies trading commodities such as cocoa, palm oil, soy, rubber, cattle, coffee, and timber must prove their products are deforestation-free. SMEs will follow by June 2026.

The stakes are high. Non-compliance can mean fines of up to 4% of annual EU turnover, blocked shipments, exclusion from public tenders, and long-term reputational damage. Yet most companies are not ready for the deep traceability that EUDR requires, right down to the plot of land where commodities originate.

This is where SAP Green Tokencomes in.

Who is affected by EUDR?

The regulation applies broadly across the supply chain:

  • First-time Operators: Companies that first place commodities on the EU market or export them from the EU. First-time operators must perform full due diligence: collecting data (Article 9), conducting risk assessments (Article 10), mitigating risks (Article 11), and DDS creation & management (Article 4).
  • Downstream Operators & Traders: Companies that make relevant products available in the EU market after they have been placed there. Their obligations focus on record-keeping and referencing upstream due diligence statements (DDS) (Article 4 + 5).
  • Non-EU Suppliers: Not directly liable under EUDR, but they must provide EU customers with verified sustainability data according to Article 9 (geolocation, deforestation-free declarations) or risk losing access to EU supply chains.

This wide scope means global coordination across suppliers, producers, importers, and traders is essential.

 Figure 1. Why EUDR matters

 

Why DDS Management is the Cornerstone

At the heart of EUDR compliance lies Due Diligence Statement (DDS) management. Every operator and trader, regardless of role, must handle DDS in some form:

  • Article 4 (Operators): Operators must create and submit DDS in TRACES, ensuring products are deforestation-free and legally produced.
  • Article 5 (Traders): Traders must manage and reference upstream DDS, keeping records to prove that due diligence was exercised earlier in the chain.
  • Article 9 (Information Requirements): Defines the detailed data each DDS must contain: from geolocation of plots of land to production details, supplier information, and legality declarations.

DDS must be submitted in the EU’s TRACES system and retained for at least five years. Without robust DDS management, companies cannot prove compliance, making it the true cornerstone of any EUDR strategy.
 

Why annual reporting is too risky

Some companies consider preparing one DDS per year to cover all volumes. On paper, this looks simpler. In reality, it creates risk:

  • One bad shipment could invalidate the entire batch.
  • Annual aggregation makes it harder to trace products back to individual plots of land.
  • Errors may only surface months later, when it’s too late to correct them without penalties.
  • Fixed annual DDS volumes may be “used up” too early, forcing resubmissions mid-year.
  • And critically: geolocation data must be collected for each batch regardless. Even if reported annually, the effort is the same — while exposing companies to much higher compliance risk.

In contrast, transactional reporting is safer and more agile:

  • Each shipment is tracked individually, limiting exposure if an issue arises.
  • Errors are detected early, reducing compliance risk and correction costs.
  • Companies maintain continuous oversight instead of year-end surprises.

This is why SAP Green Token is purpose-built for transaction-level traceability and not annual summaries.

 Figure 2. Green Token - Inbounds overview for EUDR

 

How SAP Green Token simplifies EUDR compliance

Green Token was designed to help companies comply with material accounting standards, such as EUDR, at scale. Here’s how:

  • Transactional-level reporting
    Captures data at the delivery level, linking each shipment to origin, sustainability data, and geolocation.
  • Built-in TRACES integration
    Automatically generates DDS, submits them into TRACES, and retrieves reference numbers back into Green Token.
  • Chain-of-custody management
    Maintains segregated accounting for multi-tier, multi-site supply chains, ensuring full auditability.  Because EUDR requires strict segregation of compliant and non-compliant flows, Green Token makes this process automated and auditable.
  • Open API for geo-spatial- and risk tools
    Connects with external geospatial and risk assessment platforms via GeoJSON, enabling Article 10 risk analysis.
  • Audit-ready by design
    Stores DDS and supporting data for 5+ years, with transparent reporting and real-time visibility for inspections.
  • Support for EU and non-EU companies
    Green Token supports operators, traders, authorized representatives, and even non-EU suppliers, enabling them to provide the data EU customers need.

The result: compliance becomes a continuous, automated process, not a manual, reactive scramble.

How it works in practice

Implementing Green Token for EUDR follows five simple steps:

  1. Capture delivery data from ERP or CSV sources.
  2. Map EUDR attributes (geolocation, supplier IDs, DDS reference numbers).
  3. Generate DDS automatically in the correct TRACES format.
  4. Integrate with TRACES to submit DDS and pull official DDS reference numbers back into Green Token.
  5. Store and report data for auditing, with full transaction-level granularity.

This streamlined approach makes it possible for even complex, global supply chains to stay compliant without creating parallel systems or manual overhead.

 Figure 3. Green Token - Set Up Overview

 

Why SAP Green Token is different 

While other solutions focus narrowly on risk assessment or certificates, SAP Green Token delivers enterprise-scale compliance:

  • Transactional-level EUDR attributes & reporting: One of the few solutions that captures DDS data (geolocation, supplier IDs, DDS references) at the shipment/delivery level, instead of relying on aggregated annual reports.
  • ERP-native integration: Reuse supplier, material, and delivery data directly from SAP ERP, no duplicate entries.
  • Scalable for complexity: Handle multi-site, multi-commodity flows and adapt to evolving regulations like EUDR and CBAM.
  • Future-proof: Already supporting Authorized Representatives (Article 6) and ready to adapt to Omnibus updates.
  • Trusted partner ecosystem: Connect with external geospatial and audit partners through open APIs.

Only SAP Green Token combines transactional granularity, DDS Management, TRACES integration, and ERP-native scalability in one platform.

EUDR is not just another compliance exercise. It’s a structural shift in how companies prove sustainability across global supply chains. For operators, traders, and suppliers alike, the key to compliance lies in accurate, auditable, and automated DDS management.

That’s why SAP Green Token is the starting point to make it happen.

👉Ready to simplify EUDR compliance across your supply chain? Explore SAP Green Token.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: All (Tax and Trade) Routes Lead to Rome
entry.content:
It’s undeniable that challenges associated to trading routes have increased with changing weather conditions such as reduced water levels in Panama Canal, decreased safety around major shipping nodes with attacks on ships in the Red Sea or piracy acts in the Strait of Malacca, economical and geopolitical instability with import tariff hikes of course, and more.

But one thing is sure: for Tax and Trade best practices, all routes safely lead to Rome. At least for this year’s SAP for Global Trade and Tax Conference, held on November 12-13th in the Eternal City.

Themed around “Resilience in Motion: Adapting to a Shifting World”, the conference will be addressing many challenges that organizations face today, including:

  • How tax experts can eliminate manual interventions, reduce risks, and streamline compliance with minimal effort
  • How to increase transparency, reduce non-compliance issues, simplify IT landscapes and increase agility to respond to new regulations
  • Enable smarter, more transparent tax management with scenario analysis, automation, and a single source of truth
  • How to streamline global trade operations to accelerate cross-border processing, and minimize costs and risks
  • Stay ahead of tariffs, sanctions and global trade challenges in a shifting world
  • Optimize end-to-end supply chain processes to enhance visibility in trade operations, achieve duty savings, and leverage self-filing for greater efficiency

 

Opening keynote

 

Setting the scene for our 2 days, the opening keynote by the Chartered Institute of Export and International Trade will provide a comprehensive overview of the key challenges and developments shaping today’s trade and customs landscape. Set against the backdrop of ongoing trade facilitation, compliance requirements, and trade defence measures, this session will delve into the complex dynamics businesses face in navigating global trade.

 

Customer and partner stories

 

As in previous years, most of the conference will of course revolve around customer and partner stories with representatives from:

 

& more to be announced

Here, you can gain tangible examples of successful real-world scenarios from experienced organizations, with numerous tax and trade topics covered including:

 

Tax business cases

 

 

 

o   Document Reporting Compliance in the Digital Age: Navigating an Ever-Evolving Landscape

o   Inside Siemens’ SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Roll Out: Challenges, Insights and Successes

o   A Solution that Sticks: tesa's SAP Rollout Across Latin America

o   Navigating the VAT Determination Journey to SAP S/4HANA Using SAP BTP

o   All Roads Lead to Compliance: Navigating Global Tax Complexity in your SAP Environment

o   Streamlining e-invoicing: How to Leverage SAP Document and Reporting Compliance

o   The Role Tax has Played in Driving the Transformation Agenda during Discovery & Beyond

o   Beyond the SAP Roadmap: Extending SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for Global E-Invoicing

o   Tax Transformation at Boehringer Ingelheim: Driving Global Compliance Through Standardisation and Automation

o   Accelerating Compliance and Efficiency: Migration to SAP S/4HANA and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance

 

o   Co-innovation Session with SAP: SAP GTS Localisation for Mexico and Brazil

o   Navigating Global Trade Complexities: A Case Study with SAP GTS Solutions

o   Lessons in Implementing SAP Global Trade Services (GTS)

o   A Customer’s Journey with SAP Watch List Screening: Strengthening Compliance and Boosting Efficiency

o   Optimising Import and Export Management with SAP Global Trade Services

o   Technology within Trade: Journey to E4H and Trade Classifier

o   Global Trade Compliance: Accelleron's Migration to SAP GTS Edition for SAP HANA 2023 on SAP RISE

o   … with more to come as we are still confirming some of the sessions!

Trade testimonials

 

 

 

Masterclasses

 

Masterclasses have been trialled – and adopted! – already at the Global Trade and Tax Conference last year. Designed for attendees seeking a deeper understanding of specific SAP solutions, Masterclasses are interactive sessions where you will have the opportunity to hear detailed insights directly from experts and ask any questions you may have.

2 Masterclasses are currently planned and more might be added as we see increased interest from both attendees and partners:

  • Live Demonstration: Ryan’s NextGen Withholding Tax Automation Solution with SAP BTP, delivered by Ryan
  • Reframing Sanctioned Party List (SPL) Screening in SAP GTS: From Legal Obligation to Strategic Advantage, presented by Pinary

 

SAP keynote, live demos and roadmap sessions

 

Kicking off the event with an exploration of how cloud technology, AI, and predictive analytics can empower businesses to not just survive but thrive in this dynamic environment of geopolitical shifts, evolving regulations, and supply chain disruptions, SAP experts in Product Management will close the conference with an overview of the latest enhancements, upcoming features, and future innovations in SAP Global Trade Services and SAP global tax management solutions.

In addition, there will also be live demos by SAP Product Management colleagues showcasing product classification by similarity, product classification by semantic understanding & legal reasoning using Generative AI, but also management of e-document processing and statutory reporting requirements with greater efficiency and control.

 

Wondering what type of content you can expect?

 

First things first: this is really a business event, designed for tax and trade practitioners to share best practices.

For instance, at a previous edition of the event, Henkel shared an insightful deep dive into how they streamlined their global trade operations using SAP Global Trade Services to move goods in a truly global business model. Their presentation illustrated how the company’s decision to embrace SAP Global Trade Services has transformed its global trade operations, increasing both business value and agility and went into some details of how the company meticulously planned and executed this global project. All with a timeline for the rollout that centred around two key elements: global scalability and agility.

 

Still not enough?

 

What about a special Women in Tech business networking lunch and evening event to enjoy Italy’s renowned culinary heritage in the very heart of Rome?

At the lunch break on the first day, PwC will host a special Women in Tech business networking lunch on the topic of “Overcoming diversity challenges in the world of technology”. This is the perfect opportunity to connect with inspiring leaders, share insights, and foster valuable relationships with fellow women professionals in the tech and finance space.

At the end of the first day, unwind after a packed day of learning and networking at our complimentary evening event, hosted by Thomson Reuters at the stylish Casa Novecento. Located in the heart of Rome, just steps from the obelisk, Casa Novecento blends tradition and modernity and will offer delegates a relaxed evening of Italian cuisine, refreshing drinks, and great company.

 

Interested in learning more about SAP for Global Trade and Tax Conference 2025?

 

If you are looking for more details, then head straight to one of the links below where you’ll find much more information than the summary shared in this short blog:

  • Event home page
  • Detailed agenda
  • Book your ticket

I really hope to see you at the event and, in the meantime, I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

entry.title: Re: Consuming on-Premise Service in CAP Project - Error “Failed to load destination” after deploymen
entry.content:
Ok, so this is the root cause: "No user token (JWT) has been provided. This is strictly necessary for 'PrincipalPropagation'."


I suggest you to follow the documentation here: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/using-services#connect-and-deploy , and probably also this part: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/using-services#forward-auth-token 

There also some other community questions on this topic, for example this one: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/failed-to-load-destination-caused-by-no-user-token-jwt-has-been-provided/qaq-p/13717839

entry.title: Re: Line item number not 0010 is missing when MRP run
entry.content:
Try with MD01 instead of MD01N, where ensure the following input parameters are maintained

  • Planning Mode = 3 (as you tried).
  • Create Purchase Requisitions = 2 (automatically).
  • Processing Key = NETCH (Net Change).

In MD01N, all the above fields may not be visible.  Even after executing MD01, if you have issue, one final test what you can perform is, execute MD02, for the problematic material. Check if the PR is created but not linked to a valid source list or info record, which might affect item visibility.

With all these, if your issue is not resolved, then, obviously, it could be due to some custom validation. Take the help of ABAP team and perform the above steps in debug mode to find out the root cause.

entry.title: Mass Download Of Attachment In SAP Document / Invoice - SAP S4HANA / FICO
entry.content:
SAP offers various functionalities to manage attachments, but the mass download of invoice attachments is not a standard, out-of-the-box feature. This is a common pain point for many SAP users, especially in Accounts Payable departments, who need to archive or audit a large volume of invoices with their corresponding attachments.

In this blog post, we will explore the different ways to achieve this, from standard transactions to custom solutions, providing a comprehensive guide for anyone looking to streamline this process.

 

The Challenge of Mass Attachment Download in SAP

Standard SAP transactions like FB03 (Display Document) or MIR4 (Display Invoice Document) allow you to view attachments individually. However, they lack a function to download a large number of attachments at once. This becomes a significant bottleneck when:

  • Auditing: You need to provide a complete set of invoices and attachments to internal or external auditors.

  • Archiving: You are migrating documents to an external content management system or preparing for a system shutdown.

  • Reporting: You need to extract a bulk of data with attachments for analytical purposes.

So, how can you tackle this challenge? Let's delve into the methods available.

 

Method 1: The Manual, Item-by-Item Approach (Not Recommended for Mass)

 

This method is only feasible for a very small number of invoices and serves as a good starting point to understand where attachments are stored.

  1. Navigate to the Invoice: Use transaction FB03 (for FI documents) or MIR4 (for Logistics Invoice Verification).

  2. Access the Services for Object icon: This is the small icon with a paperclip and a piece of paper, typically found in the top-left corner of the screen.

  3. View and Download: From the dropdown menu, select Attachment list. A window will pop up showing all the attachments linked to that document. You can then select and download each one individually.

Why this isn't a long-term solution: This process is extremely time-consuming and prone to human error. It's simply not practical for mass downloads.

 

Method 2: The Semi-Automated SO_OBJECT_DOWNLOAD Function Module

 

For those with some technical know-how, this method provides a way to download attachments programmatically, but still on a document-by-document basis.

  1. Identify the Document Key: Each attachment is linked to an object key in SAP. You can find this by navigating to SOBJ table or through the attachment list pop-up screen.

  2. Execute SO_OBJECT_DOWNLOAD: Go to transaction SE37 and execute the function module SO_OBJECT_DOWNLOAD.

  3. Provide the Object Key: In the function module parameters, input the object key of the attachment you want to download. You can then execute it to save the file to your local drive.

Limitations: This method is still not a true "mass" download solution. It requires you to know the object key for each attachment, which means you would need to write a custom program to get this data in the first place.

 

Method 3: The Custom ABAP Program (The Most Effective Solution)

 

This is the most common and robust solution for mass downloads. It requires the expertise of an ABAP developer but provides the flexibility to meet your specific business requirements.

How a Custom Program Works:

A well-designed ABAP program for mass downloads would typically follow these steps:

  1. Input Parameters: The program should have a selection screen where the user can input a range of invoice document numbers, vendor numbers, posting dates, or other relevant criteria.

  2. Retrieve Document List: The program will read the relevant SAP tables (e.g., BKPF for document headers, RSEG for invoice documents) to get a list of all invoices that meet the selection criteria.

  3. Link to Attachments: For each invoice document found, the program will query the attachment tables. The primary tables for object links are SRGBTBREL (Relations between Business Objects) and SOFFCONT1 (the actual content of the documents).

  4. Download and Save: The program will then loop through each attachment found, retrieve its content from SOFFCONT1, and save it to a specified folder on the user's local machine or a network drive. The filename can be dynamically generated using the invoice number, vendor number, or other relevant data for easy identification.

  5. Logging and Reporting: The program should generate a log showing which documents were processed, which attachments were downloaded successfully, and which ones failed (e.g., if there was no attachment).

*&--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report:           ZFI_INV_DOWN_ATTACH
*& Description:      Report to Download FB03 attachments
*&--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Date          Developer    Transport         Change/Description
*&----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
REPORT zfi_inv_down_attach.
TABLES : bkpf,regup.

TYPES : BEGIN OF gty_bkpf ,
          bukrs TYPE bkpf-bukrs,
          belnr TYPE bkpf-belnr,
          gjahr TYPE bkpf-gjahr,
        END OF gty_bkpf.
TYPES : BEGIN OF gty_output ,
          files TYPE string,
          bukrs TYPE bkpf-bukrs,
          gjahr TYPE bkpf-gjahr,
          belnr TYPE bkpf-belnr,
        END OF gty_output.
DATA: lt_bkpf    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gty_bkpf,
      ls_bkpf    TYPE gty_bkpf,
      lt_output  TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gty_output,
      lt_output1 TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gty_output,
      ls_output  TYPE gty_output.
DATA: o_alv    TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table,
      o_cols   TYPE REF TO cl_salv_columns,
      o_column TYPE REF TO cl_salv_column.

DATA: o_layout  TYPE REF TO cl_salv_layout,
      key       TYPE salv_s_layout_key,
      g_exit    TYPE c,
      lx_msg    TYPE REF TO cx_salv_msg,
      g_variant TYPE disvariant,
      set_lay   TYPE slis_vari.


SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b4 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-s04.
  PARAMETERS : r1 RADIOBUTTON GROUP g1 USER-COMMAND cmd DEFAULT 'X',
               r2 RADIOBUTTON GROUP g1.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b4.

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b1 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-s01.
  SELECT-OPTIONS: so_BELNR FOR bkpf-belnr  NO INTERVALS MODIF ID Rb1.
  PARAMETERS: p_bukrs TYPE bkpf-bukrs MODIF ID rb1,
              p_gjahr TYPE bkpf-gjahr MODIF ID rb1.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b1.

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b2 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-s02.
  PARAMETERS: p_LAUFD TYPE regup-laufd MODIF ID rb2,
              p_LAUFI TYPE regup-laufi MODIF ID rb2,
              p_XVORL TYPE regup-xvorl AS CHECKBOX MODIF ID rb2,
              p_ZBUKR TYPE regup-zbukr MODIF ID rb2.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b2.
SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b3 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-s03.
  PARAMETERS : p_file TYPE string.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b3.

.

AT SELECTION-SCREEN OUTPUT.
  LOOP AT SCREEN.
    IF screen-group1 = 'RB2' AND r1 EQ 'X'.
      screen-active = '0'.
      MODIFY SCREEN.
      CONTINUE.
    ELSEIF screen-group1 = 'RB1' AND r2 EQ 'X'.
      screen-active = '0'.
      MODIFY SCREEN.
      CONTINUE.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.

*AT SELECTION-SCREEN.


AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_file.
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>directory_browse
    CHANGING
      selected_folder      = p_file
    EXCEPTIONS
      cntl_error           = 1
      error_no_gui         = 2
      not_supported_by_gui = 3
      OTHERS               = 4.

  IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
*    f_pathname = f_path.
*    WRITE: f_pathname.
  ENDIF.

START-OF-SELECTION .

  IF r1 EQ abap_true.
    IF so_belnr IS NOT INITIAL AND p_bukrs IS NOT INITIAL AND p_gjahr IS NOT INITIAL.
    ELSE.
      MESSAGE 'Please enter all fields' TYPE 'E'.
    ENDIF.
  ELSEIF r2 EQ abap_true.
    IF p_laufd IS NOT INITIAL AND p_laufi IS NOT INITIAL AND p_zbukr IS NOT INITIAL.
    ELSE.
      MESSAGE 'Please enter all fields' TYPE 'E'.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.





  IF r1 EQ abap_true.
    SELECT bukrs, belnr, gjahr
   FROM bkpf
   WHERE
   belnr IN _belnr
   AND bukrs = @p_bukrs AND gjahr = @p_gjahr
   INTO TABLE _bkpf.


  ELSEIF r2 EQ abap_true.

    SELECT laufd,laufi,xvorl,zbukr,bukrs,belnr,gjahr
      FROM regup
      INTO TABLE (lt_regup)
      WHERE
      laufd = @p_laufd AND
      laufi = @p_laufi AND
      xvorl = @p_xvorl AND
      zbukr = @p_zbukr.
    IF sy-subrc EQ 0 .
      SELECT bukrs, belnr, gjahr
        FROM bkpf
        FOR ALL ENTRIES IN _regup
        WHERE bukrs = _regup-zbukr
        AND belnr = _regup-belnr
        AND gjahr = _regup-gjahr

        INTO TABLE _bkpf.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.
  IF lt_bkpf IS NOT INITIAL.
    SORT lt_bkpf BY belnr bukrs gjahr.
    DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM lt_bkpf COMPARING ALL FIELDS.
    LOOP AT lt_bkpf INTO ls_bkpf.
      PERFORM download USING ls_bkpf.
    ENDLOOP.
    IF lt_output IS NOT INITIAL.
      TRY.
          cl_salv_table=>factory(
            IMPORTING
              r_salv_table = o_alv
            CHANGING
              t_table      = lt_output ).
        CATCH cx_salv_msg INTO lx_msg.
      ENDTRY.

      CALL METHOD o_alv->get_layout
        RECEIVING
          value = o_layout.

      CALL METHOD o_layout->set_key
        EXPORTING
          value = key.

      CALL METHOD o_layout->set_save_restriction
        EXPORTING
          value = if_salv_c_layout=>restrict_none.

      o_cols = o_alv->get_columns( ).
      TRY.
          o_column = o_cols->get_column( 'FILES' ).
          o_column->set_long_text( 'Downloaded Files' ).
          o_column->set_medium_text( 'Downloaded Files' ).
          o_column->set_short_text( 'Files' ).
          o_column->set_output_length( 50 ).
        CATCH cx_salv_not_found.                        "#EC NO_HANDLER
      ENDTRY.


      o_alv->get_functions( )->set_all( ).

*   set the Column optimization
      o_cols->set_optimize( 'X' ).

      o_alv->display( ).

    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Form download
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& text
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&      --> LS_BKPF
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM download  USING    p_ls_bkpf TYPE gty_bkpf.
  DATA: ls_object        TYPE sibflporb,
        lt_objects       TYPE sibflporbt,
        doc_id           TYPE sofolenti1-doc_id,
        lt_doc_id        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF srgbtbrel,
        lt_links_a       TYPE obl_t_link,
        lt_links_b       TYPE obl_t_link,
        lt_objectheader  TYPE srm_t_solisti1,
        lt_objectcontent TYPE srm_t_solisti1,
        lt_content_hex   TYPE tabtype_solix,
        ls_doc_data      TYPE sofolenti1,
        lt_links_table   TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF srgbtbrel,
        lt_att           TYPE solix_tab,
        lv_lin           TYPE i,
        lv_length        TYPE i,
        lv_doc_id        TYPE sofolenti1-doc_id,
        lv_xstring       TYPE xstring,
        lv_filename      TYPE string,
        lvfile           TYPE string,
        lv_ext           TYPE char4,
        lv_index         TYPE char4.

  CONSTANTS : lv_fil TYPE char15 VALUE '*XFLOW INVOICE*'.

  ls_object-instid = p_ls_bkpf-bukrs && p_ls_bkpf-belnr && p_ls_bkpf-gjahr.
  SELECT * FROM srgbtbrel INTO TABLE lt_links_table
       WHERE instid_a = ls_object-instid.
  IF sy-subrc EQ 0 .


    LOOP AT lt_links_table INTO DATA(ls_links).
      MOVE ls_links-instid_b TO doc_id.
      CLEAR :ls_doc_data,lt_content_hex,lt_objectcontent,lt_objectheader,lv_length.
      CALL FUNCTION 'SO_DOCUMENT_READ_API1'
        EXPORTING
          document_id                = doc_id
*         FILTER                     = 'X '
        IMPORTING
          document_data              = ls_doc_data
        TABLES
          object_header              = lt_objectheader
          object_content             = lt_objectcontent
          contents_hex               = lt_content_hex
        EXCEPTIONS
          document_id_not_exist      = 1
          operation_no_authorization = 2
          x_error                    = 3
          OTHERS                     = 4.

*       Convert content of file from SOLIX to XSTRING
*      es_doc_info = ls_doc_data.
      TRANSLATE ls_doc_data-obj_descr TO UPPER CASE.
      IF ls_doc_data-obj_descr CP lv_fil.
        APPEND ls_links TO lt_doc_id.
        CLEAR doc_id.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.

    DESCRIBE TABLE lt_doc_id LINES DATA(lv_lines).
    IF lv_lines GT 1.
      DATA(lv_MULT) = abap_true.
    ENDIF.

*    DELETE lt_links_table WHERE instid_b NOT IN lt_doc_id.

    LOOP AT lt_doc_id INTO DATA(lw_links).
      WRITE sy-tabix TO lv_index.
      MOVE lw_links-instid_b TO doc_id.
      CLEAR :ls_doc_data,lt_content_hex,lt_objectcontent,lt_objectheader,lv_length.
      CALL FUNCTION 'SO_DOCUMENT_READ_API1'
        EXPORTING
          document_id                = doc_id
*         FILTER                     = 'X '
        IMPORTING
          document_data              = ls_doc_data
        TABLES
          object_header              = lt_objectheader
          object_content             = lt_objectcontent
          contents_hex               = lt_content_hex
        EXCEPTIONS
          document_id_not_exist      = 1
          operation_no_authorization = 2
          x_error                    = 3
          OTHERS                     = 4.

*       Convert content of file from SOLIX to XSTRING
*      es_doc_info = ls_doc_data.
      TRANSLATE ls_doc_data-obj_descr TO UPPER CASE.
      IF ls_doc_data-obj_descr CP lv_fil.
        lv_length = ls_doc_data-doc_size.
        IF lt_content_hex IS NOT INITIAL.
          CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BINARY_TO_XSTRING'
            EXPORTING
              input_length = lv_length
            IMPORTING
              buffer       = lv_xstring
            TABLES
              binary_tab   = lt_content_hex
            EXCEPTIONS ##FM_SUBRC_OK
              failed       = 1
              OTHERS       = 2.
        ENDIF.

* 2. Download to File
        lv_filename = p_file ."'. " Or any desired filename
        IF ls_doc_data-obj_type EQ 'XLS'.
          lv_ext = 'XLSX'.
        ELSEIF  ls_doc_data-obj_type = 'DOC'.
          lv_ext = 'DOCX'.
        ELSE.
          lv_ext = ls_doc_data-obj_type.
        ENDIF.

        CONCATENATE ls_object-instid '_' ls_doc_data-obj_descr INTO lv_filename.

        IF lv_mult EQ abap_true.
          CONDENSE lv_index.
          CONCATENATE p_ls_bkpf-belnr '_' lv_index INTO lv_filename.
        ELSE.
          lv_filename = p_ls_bkpf-belnr  .
        ENDIF.
        CONCATENATE p_file '\' lv_filename '.' lv_ext INTO lvfile.
        ls_output-files = lv_filename && '.' && lv_ext.
        ls_output-belnr = p_ls_bkpf-belnr.
        ls_output-gjahr = p_ls_bkpf-gjahr.
        ls_output-bukrs = p_ls_bkpf-bukrs.
        CALL FUNCTION 'GUI_DOWNLOAD'
          EXPORTING
            filename = lvfile
            filetype = 'BIN'
          TABLES
            data_tab = lt_content_hex.
        IF sy-subrc EQ 0 .
          APPEND ls_output TO lt_output.
          CLEAR ls_output.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.
ENDFORM.

 

Testing :

Open the transaction code 

 

 

Populated details of:

 

Search with Doc NoManually paste/type the document number desires
Company CodeXXXX
Fiscal Year2025
Directory path for file downloadTemp

 

 

Execute

Please wait for the downloading to be done

 

 

Benefits of a Custom Program:

  • Automation: Automates the entire process, saving countless hours of manual work.

  • Flexibility: Can be customized to filter by any criteria and save files in a specific naming convention.

  • Scalability: Can handle hundreds or even thousands of invoices at a time.

Conclusion

While SAP provides standard functionalities for viewing individual attachments, a mass download capability is not part of the standard offering. For true mass downloads, a custom ABAP program is the most efficient and recommended solution. It's a one-time development effort that can save significant time and effort in the long run, particularly for Accounts Payable teams, auditors, and IT administrators.

If you are facing this challenge, consider reaching out to your in-house ABAP team or an SAP consulting partner to develop a custom solution that fits your business needs perfectly.

entry.title: Re: Sap avc parent child character relationship in public...
entry.content:
Hi @ankit_1662 

Thank you for your question.

The Advanced Variant Configuration Capabilities in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are very streamlined compared to on-premise or private cloud.

Based on the details, you are trying to use Z-tables or custom tables like AVC_WRP in your example inside constraints and this is not possible in the Public Cloud. You cannot write free form dependency code because only the dependency syntax released by SAP is allowed. Extensibility is limited to whitelisted enhancement options when integration AVC with custom lookup logic.

You have the option to model dependencies with preconditions where you define one that ties it to the correct parent value. Public Cloud AVC is designed for simplified modelling, therefore ensure you keep the model and dependency simple with few layers of conditions.

Consider the following links for more information.

Variant Configuration in S/4HANA Cloud

Scope item 6GU- Advanced Variant Configuration

I hope this provides the desired insights. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: You are not authorized to query the remote system. Pl...
entry.content:
This message means your user account doesn’t have the necessary permissions to access the remote system — specifically, you’re missing the InA (Information Access) role.

To resolve this:

  1. Contact your system administrator or whoever manages roles/permissions in your organization.

  2. Ask them to assign you the InA role on the remote system you're trying to query.

  3. Once the role is granted, you should be able to access the data without issues.

If you're unsure who the admin is, check with your IT team or platform owner — they’ll usually know who can manage user roles.

entry.title: Re: Standard outbound idoc don't send specific fields
entry.content:
Unfortunately, there is no direct configuration or transaction code that allows you to selectively exclude or blank out fields in a standard outbound IDoc without coding, user exits, or modifying the IDoc type.

SAP always fills the fields based on the standard function module logic like IDOC_OUTPUT_INVOIC. To suppress fields, you would need a custom function module assigned in WE20, Or a user exit / enhancement like EXIT_SAPLVV01_001 for INVOIC.

entry.title: Re: Self Service Procure cookbook doesn't describe how th...
entry.content:
Hello @Robson1 

Thanks for your update. To clarify, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you cannot use PA30, PA40, or PPOMA. These transactions are exclusive to on-premises HR and Organisational Management.

For Public Cloud, please verify the following carefully

Assign the catalogue to the user
Use the app Default Settings for Users – Purchase Requisitions to set the user’s Default Procurement → Catalogue.
SAP Help Portal – Default Settings for Users

Load and index catalogue items
Run the job Schedule Import of Catalogue Data so that items are indexed and visible in Cross-Catalogue Search.
 SAP Help Portal – Schedule Import of Catalogue Data

Authorisation
Ensure the user has access to My Purchase Requisitions – New (F1639A) through a role such as Employee Procurement.

Troubleshooting
If items still don’t appear, check SAP KBA 2680363 Internal catalogue items cannot be found in Cross-Catalogue Search.” Sometimes, rerunning the import job fixes the issue.

No PA30 or PPOMA is needed; all is handled via Cloud apps and catalogue indexing.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Blocked Sales Order
Re: GLT2201 - Balancing field "Business Area" in line ite...
entry.content:
It seems, Document splitting is activated in your system where Business Area is defined as a mandatory splitting characteristic. During MIGO, the system tries to create accounting entries but cannot determine the Business Area for one or more lines. The account assignment which is nothing but cost center or internal order is missing or incomplete and the plant-to-business area mapping is not maintained.

When performing MIGO, what Account Assignment is flowing ? If you are using a cost center, make sure it has a valid Business Area. If not, consider assigning one or using a substitution rule.

Go to OBBH, create a rule to derive Business Area based on plant, cost center, or other logic.

Finally, check whether you need to carry out code corrections as recommended in SAP note 2574432

entry.title: Re: FI: Opening balance change
entry.content:
Hi @nithin_pranesh 

Yes, you can adjust your inventory and asset balances as of 31st Dec 2024 but be sure to carefully follow SAP’s standard procedures for corrections after operational entries have already been posted into 2025.

  • In doing this please note that opening balances should match audited figures and corrections are frequently required after audit.
  • Since you have proceeded with depreciation and postings for 2025, you cannot directly overwrite the previously uploaded balances. You must adjust them by using special postings for the prior period.

I have listed below ways you can carry out the changes and what you should take note of in doing it. 

  1. To carry out the adjustments, post Value Adjustments for Opening Balances through manual subsequent postings by using the Fiori App Carry Forward Balances for Ledger Groups. This process creates adjustment entries posted to period 0 or a special adjustment period in December to correct opening balances without interfering with your current year’s operations.
  2. Ensure to make use of the special adjustment periods for corrections after the fiscal year is closed but before annual closing make use of an adjustment period. This will ensure your corrections are posted as adjusting journal entries dated 31.12.2024, with necessary documentation marking them as audit adjustments. This ensure your changes flow into 2025 and are reflected in your reporting correclt.
  3. For your assets, make use of the Adjustment to Asset Block Opening WDV or Transactions app to adjust the opening Written Down Value (WDV) or acquisition values as of the opening date. Enter all relevant details.
  4. For your inventory, ensure to post an adjustment as of 31st Dec 2024, thereby you mark the entry as an opening balance correction. Ensure this is aligned with your reconciliation and that inventory G/Ls are properly impacted.

Please note, all your subsequent postings, whether depreciation, stock movement, etc. for 2025 will remain valid. Adjustment entries will only affect values as of Dec 31, 2024. Ensure you document for audit reasons. It is important to coordinate these with your finance team and SAP support.

I hope this provides the desired insights. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

 

Post Value Adjustments for Opening Balances

Adjustment after year end closing

Adjust Book Inventory

entry.title: Completing the B2B migration into SAP Integration Suite vision
entry.content:
The last part to be migrated is the B2B integrations you have like EDIFACT, X12 or what formats you are using. The official guidance is to use MIG and MAGs to handle the migration.

It is not really ideal because it will require a large investment in recreation of all your partner mappings. There can be cases where it make sense and a good way to streamline your B2B setup. Many of your partner mappings have probably not been touched for years.

SAP has also published a version of a way to handle the migrations. That will allow you to reuse the mappings. Do give it a try to see how it will work for you.

I published something about our vision for the migration 2 years ago about how I saw that you could migrate to it.

We have now completed this journey about making it possible to perform the migration in an end to end flow. I would say it is much more complete than I had expected. It now feels like a smooth process with tooling that supports you all the way.

We wanted to create a tool that extended the standard usage of SAP TPM, but removed some of the biggest challenges that exists when working with it.

Can the migration work

We and one of our partners have been able to work with the initial version of the migration. It has been possible to retrain the message mapping and perform small changes in the used Java, UDF, XSLT to make it work.

We created a simple iflow with Process Direct and then the mappings that had been migrated with Figaf. We also added a XML formatter that translated between SAP PI B2B format and the MIG format.

Our customer said that the message mappings were not causing any problems.

But the strategy work and you can run your migration this way.

End to end Flow

Here is an example of how this works end-to-end and shows you that the migration is possible.

 Steps in the migration

 Test data recording from SAP PI

Before you can migrate your integration, you must have some test cases. Here we can record messages from SAP PI and filter one the content to find the message for the correct partners. This is something we have had for a long time.

Partner creation

We have added a streamlined way to create partners. Currently you need to fill in a lot of different values and if you will need to create a partner.

Then you get partners created in a standard and consisted way with identifies and connected system. This will make the transport process easier.

There are still going to be some manual changes that you will need to fill for the adapters but this should simplify your operation.

Migration overview

We have built a specific overview of how your migration is going. This is going to make it easier to see what you have migrated and what still is missing. You can see what is migrated to what agreements.

 

Operation mapping migration

We have decided to migrate from Operation Mapping and then convert it to Process Direct flow. Here you can use Figaf functions for converting UDF to groovy, or use the Cloud Integration Function Libraries. We recommend that you migrate the TPM lookup to Groovy because then you can easy get to find and replace the functions that you need.

To create the agreement you need to select

  • Self

  • Partner

  • Agreement template (yes you need to create them with MAGs, to easily find MIGs used)

  • Then you from the dropdown can fill in the information used in the Agreement

Once everything is filled in correctly you just click migrate which will create all the objects needed.

We do support the use of generic mappings, if you want to use the target iflows consistently.  

 Testing

Once you have deployed the flow and the agreement, you can migrate the test. Then the test case can run on the TPM flows.

Then you will need to perform the corrections to ensure it produces the correct result.

The cool part about this is that you can keep the test cases and use them when something change either to the Integration Suite, or you need to change something else as a part of the maintenance of your partners.

Road map

We are currently working on a way that allows you to transport the Agreements as we do for all the other objects. This will make it much easier to have one way to manage all integrations.

Learn more

You can explore this with our free migration edition, which will allow you to migrate 10 Operations mappings and test them.

There are several prerequisite steps that you need to follow to create a solid foundation. You can see the steps here. You can see this guide.

entry.title: Re: RM07DOCS dumped with TSV_TNEW_PAGE_ALLOC_FAILED
entry.content:
You need to convince your BA and educate him/her that MB51 is a powerful report, but it’s designed to work best when we help it narrow down the data. When we run it with only plant as a filter, it tries to pull millions of records, which is why it crashes or runs out of memory. By adding filters like Posting Date or Movement Type, we’re not limiting your access — we’re making sure you get the data faster, more reliably, and without system errors.

Still if you are not able to convince, then, you can create a screen variant for mb51 via shd0 with pre-filled values like plant, posting date. Assign it to a user or role. This lets your Business Analyst run MB51 with default filters, even if they don’t manually enter them.

The other option is to create ZMB51 which should be copy of RM07DOCS Program, where you can add standard variant via se38 or se80 where you can include default filters like Posting Date, Movement Type, etc. This gives full control and avoids dumps — especially useful if MB51 is used frequently with minimal filters.

But again, the current practice is strictly not recommended and if needed, you need to take it up to next level

entry.title: Re: Rebate and Royalties in SAP S/4
entry.content:
Hi @sumit_chourasia1 ,

SAP Condition Contract Settlement does not create SD Billing Documents: "Settlement in Condition Contract Management is posted through a Settlement Document directly to FI, so posting through an SD invoice is no longer possible". See 2815535 - FAQ: Condition Contract Management by Settlement Management in SAP S/4HANA - SAP for Me.

It is possible to use multiple data sources for the business volume. For this you have to configure "Additional Business Volume Tables" within the "Profiles for Business Volume Determination". An example for a table that is reading settlement documents is  C_SETLDOCITMSCOMMSNBIZVOL. You find this example in the document CCM_External_Sales_Commissions_Standard_Configuration_2023.pdf. See 2535889 - CCM - Description of delivered configuration - SAP for Me.

Helpful reading: Settlement Management | SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Error while uploading PDF file in "Create supplier in...
entry.content:
Hello @Varun_Arora1 

Thank you for your question.

The error on your attached screenshot is a known issue in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and Fiori apps. This error typically results from either the file not being properly selected, a problem with your Content Version attachment services or a missing parameter in document management configuration.

  • Ensure the PDF file is valid, not empty and correctly selected before clicking upload. You can reselect and again.
  • Consider clearing your browser cache and try a different browser or incognito window.
  • Make sure your SAP DMS is configured and enabled in your environment, as attachments in Fiori rely on corresponding content management settings.

Sometimes, it has happened that backend permissions or temporary system blocks especially after you have carried out migration activities can prevent generating a valid file ID for attachment.

You can open an incident with SAP if the error persists.

The SAP KBA on attachment upload errors provides further details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Keeping Positions in Sync with Job Info Portlet in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
entry.content:
Agenda

  1. Why Job Info → Position sunchornization matters
  2. Step-by-step configuration with Business Rules
  3. Role of Event Reasons
  4. Best practices to avoid errors
  5. Final thoughts

Why positions and job info must match in Successfactors Employee Central?

Position and Job Info Both should Match. Usually positions have tendency to sync data to job info. That means if you get 1 new update in position then those information can be automatically populated from Position Job Info Via position to Job Info Synchronization.

Why Job Info and Position must match in Successfactors Employee Central?

  • If you have different information on employee profile and on a position, how can you recognize the correct information?
  • So, You need to sync both to avoid mismatch info. If you are not using sync then you're losing automation as the data from the position.
  • In configuration using position management, only use Position-to-Job Info synchronization direction. I strongly recommend you to use Position to Job info Sync in Manage Position management settings to reduce the User error.

How Synchronization works:

  • Go to "Position Management Settings".
  • Navigate to the "Synchronization Tab".
    • The "Synchronization Tab" determines the behavior of the system when synchronizing data from a Position to an employee’s Job Information. This includes the rules for defining fields used in synchronization of Position to an employee’s Job Information.
  • Configure the fields that should sync
  • Add Business Rules for triggering updates (e.g., when a position is changed, reflect changes in Job Info).

Step-by-Step: Position to JobInfo Sync Configuration with Business Rule:

Define the Use Case:

  • When a change happens in the Job Information Portlet  (like Department, Division, Location), it should automatically reflect in the Position Object.
  • This is handled via a Business Rule using the Scenario: Synchronize Incumbent’s Changes to Position Scenario.

Step: 1 - Create the Business Rule:

  1. Go to Configure Business Rules.

  2. Click Create New Rule.

  3. Choose Position Management  - Pre Delivered Template. 

  4. Under Scenario, select: Synchronize Incumbent’s Changes to Position Scenario.

Step 2 - Register the Rule in Position Management Settings:

  1. Go to Admin Center → Position Management Settings.

  2. Navigate to the Synchronization Tab.

  3. Find the field: "Rule for Synchronizing Job Information to Position".

  4. Assign the Business Rule you just created (JobToPos)

  5. Save the configuration.

Step: 3 Event Reason object configuration

  • Event Reasons act as triggers for synchronization.
  • Common examples:
    • Position Transfer → when an employee moves to a new role.
      • If you are going to change the position then position transfer will be use as follow up activity.
    • Position Reclassification → when department/division updates occur.
      • If you want to change in department and Division then Position Reclassification will be use as follow up activity.
  • These objects ensure accurate, event-driven updates.
  • For the Job info to position Synchronization we need to get help from event reason. On the base of event reason we will get change. Mainly we creates three objects event reason to change happen from Job info to position.

Step: 4 job information portlet and create Business Rule

Prerequisite:

  • First you need to go to Job Information Portlet and check here if we have Event and Event Reason Picklist field is enabled or not.
  • If its enabled and will be visible there then we don’t need to write the business rule for this case user will select manually.
  • If its not enabled then event and event reason will not come up here so we have write the business rule.

Regards,

Mahnoor Naseem

SAP SuccessFactors Consultant

If you found this blog a useful please consider giving it a Kudos

entry.title: Re: Error creating number group range for range object: E...
entry.content:
Hola @MatiasGarciaKPS 

Thanks for your message. In SAP S/4HANA, Public Cloud, the number range object for eDocument Spain – Verifactu (EDOC_ESVF) is delivered as SAP-controlled. This is why the fields appear read-only and why the Copy Subobject option leads to an authorisation error; the system does not allow customers to create or extend ranges for this object.

If you need separate number ranges for multiple companies, the recommended path is to open an SAP Incident under component CA-GTF-CSC-EDO (eDocument Compliance). SAP Support can then confirm whether an enhancement or additional SSCUI option is available for your release.

Check below SAP help references:

SAP Help Portal – Spain: Electronic Invoicing with Verifactu

3609812 - FAQ - Electronic Document Processing for Spain VERI*FACTU legal change 2025/2026

SAP Help-Using Evaluated Invoice Settlement

In summary, the observed behaviour is deliberate in Public Cloud, and new ranges for EDOC_ESVF cannot be created directly.

Feel free to reach out when ever you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Building an Attachment Upload and Download Solution Using UploadSetwithTable Control
entry.content:
Hi @tejaswikosanam as I mentioned above, your scenario should be achievable.

When you click upload, you have to create the binding without sending the patch request, which should update the table locally on the UI. Later, when you press the save, you can send your local changes to the backend.

Give it a try in this direction.

An answer to your question in the community:  You can skip the default uploader and use your implementation the same way I am using it in this blog post. All you have to do is put the uploader under the aggregation uploader.

<uploader>
<upload.UploaderTableItem httpRequestMethod="Put"/>
</uploader>

entry.title: SAP Community Team Spotlight: Josh Bentley - September 2025 Edition
entry.content:
You probably have already seen the past interviews of this series (one / two / three / four / five / six / seven / eight ) which were done by my colleague Marco Santos. Today I am very excited to introduce you to another amazing person behind the SAP Community platform. Here we are with another SAP Community Spotlight, @josh_bentley ! 

 

Fatemeh Zarei (FZ): Hi Josh! Thank you so much for joining us today. To kick things off - would you like to tell us a little bit about your iconic blue beard? How did that all start?

Josh Bentley: So, every superhero has their own origin story - mine's just a little less dramatic. I’ve been talking about technology for nearly 25 years, and in 2018, I joined the Developer Advocates team after leaving the Cloud Center of Excellence. At a conference - SAP TechEd - the women on our team had all these vibrant hair colors and teased us guys for being boring. I thought, “Why is it only the women showing personality?” But I don’t have hair - I’m bald! So, one of them said, “Well, you can dye your beard.” I didn’t take it seriously at first, but before SAP TechEd in 2019, I thought, "Why not?" I texted her for tips, used paper towels to mix colors until I got close to SAP blue, and I’ve kept it ever since. This October marks six years! What keeps me doing it is not just for my ego boost but for the smiles I get from others and the joy they truly show me when they see me.

FZ: That’s fantastic! Now, shifting gears a bit - how did you first get involved with the SAP Community?

Josh: That goes back to my pre-sales days, around 2011 or 2012, when we had the “Blog It Forward” campaign that Moshe Naveh started. I was a solution engineer at the time and joined in by answering the campaign questions, then tagging others. That was my first real blog post and entry into the community. I wasn’t one of the founders or key players at the start - it was more of a resource to find answers or share thoughts. But that’s where it began for me.

FZ: What's your current role on the SAP Community team, and what does a typical day look like?

Josh: These days, I focus on promoting community advocacy. I help highlight what’s working and where we can improve. My work is all about connecting with people - online and in person - and making sure their voices are heard. There’s no “typical” day, but it involves a mix of content creation, listening to feedback, and strategizing how to make the community better.

FZ: You’ve done so much! What’s one part of the SAP community experience that you’re particularly proud of?

Josh: It’s hard to pick one, but I’ll mention three chapters in my SAP life. First, I was part of the team that transitioned SAP from BlackBerry to Apple devices, which was a major enterprise shift. We tackled security, analytics access, BYOD - it was a huge cross-functional effort. Then in pre-sales, I traveled extensively and gave technical demos to some of the biggest companies in the world. I got comfortable and confident in front of customers because I prepared so thoroughly - “sharpening the axe,” as they say. And in the Developer Advocate role, one big highlight was being trusted to go on stage for SAP TechEd, even during the COVID era when we broadcasted from Frankfurt. Being able to be myself and present on a global stage was unforgettable.

FZ: Amazing. Do you have a favorite or most memorable moment in the community?

Josh: One standout was my first SAP TechEd in Barcelona. Being in a role where I get to visit an amazing city like that is something else, but the real magic was seeing the show floor and the scale of how many SAP mentors and other legacy members made the trip. Some of my first SAP selfies with people I would work with for years were taken at that event.

FZ: How do you stay in tune with the community’s needs and feedback?

Josh: Three main ways. First, in-person events. That’s where people are really open. Online, they might not comment or engage as much, but in person they’ll say, “Hey, I saw your video!” Second, I post on YouTube and LinkedIn to keep communication flowing. Third, I look at outside platforms like Reddit or Stack Overflow to see what SAP techies are saying in the wild.

FZ: If you could wave a magic wand and change one thing in the community, what would it be?

Josh: I’d love to see more people offering constructive feedback - with solutions in mind. Not just “this is broken,” but “here’s how it could be better.” I know we can’t always implement every suggestion - due to technology limitations or staffing - but the community is stronger when members help shape it. The community is bigger than just a website. It’s every conversation, every event. And we need our members to be co-owners in it.

FZ: And one final question - do you have any advice for those new to SAP or the SAP Community, like me?

Josh: Absolutely. Be your own advocate. No one else is going to push you harder than you will. Learn how your managers listen. In meetings - listen first. Figure out how you can add value. People ask how they can have a role like mine. I say, there are two ways: either start a company and create your own path - or gain experience over time. I didn’t go to school for SAP. I started wiring buildings, setting up IT systems, and just kept learning. Over time, I built a brand and a reputation for being honest, responsive, and knowledgeable. Have a point of view - or put in the work. There’s no shortcut. Just engage with kindness and curiosity, and the rest will come.

FZ:  What a wonderful way to wrap things up! Thank you so much, Josh, for joining me today and sharing your SAP journey with us. It’s been a real pleasure having you here.

Josh: Thanks, Fatemeh. I really enjoyed our conversation.

entry.title: Re: Send Stock SAP MM to another application
entry.content:
Yes via message type MBGMCR, SAP can send IDocs automatically when a material document is posted, depending on your setup. You’ll need to configure output type in NACE for application MB. Assign a partner profile in WE20 and ensure the function module like IDOC_OUTPUT_WMMBXY is active. The advantage of having this set up is easy to monitor via WE02/WE05 and can be extended with user exits if needed. but on the other side, this requires IDoc infrastructure and mapping on the third-party side.

The other option is BAdI MB_DOCUMENT_BADI or EXIT_SAPMM07M_001 to intercept MIGO posting. From there, trigger a custom API call, a queue Or even write to a Z-table for later extraction. The advantage of going with this approach are full control over payload and timing and can be tailored to specific movement types. On the other side, it involves risk of performance impact if not handled asynchronously.

If your third-party system supports IDoc or can consume it via middleware like PI/CPI, go with Option 1 (IDoc MBGMCR or WMMBXY). It is clean, standard, and scalable. If you need real-time push with custom payload, go with Option 2 (BAdI) and trigger a REST API or queue.

entry.content:

  2. Also, start a test execution from a test plan with the same test case as above.
  3. Try to delete the test execution from step one while keeping the exectution from step two.
